titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Kimbei Kusakabe photograph album with costumes, portraits, occupations, and views of Japan, between 1885-1890 RL.11696
titlestmt.author: Paula Jeannet

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-05-06 12:00:34 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Kimbei Kusakabe photograph album with costumes, portraits, occupations, and views of Japan

physdesc.physfacet: 100 hand-colored albumen prints on card stock mounts; 1 presentation box; 2 lacquer covers.

did.abstract: Large souvenir folio album from the Yokohama studio of Japanese photographer Kimbei Kusakabe, featuring 100 hand-tinted albumen prints on original mounts, most with title labels in English. Also included are the highly decorated black lacquer covers and original presentation box. Most of the prints measure approximately 8 1/8 x 10 3/8 inches; the mounts are sized 10 1/4 x 14 inches. Images were designed to appeal to tourists, and portray crafts and trades; rice cultivation; tea houses; hotels, gardens, temples, and other scenes, mostly in Kyoto, but also including Kobe, Yamato, Nagasaki, and Arima. Portraits of people include: geishas bathing, playing musical instruments, and dressing; Samurais and Sumo wrestlers; rural inhabitants; a physician; a rickshaw and passengers; a funeral; and numerous other subjects typical of these albums. A few of the prints are attributed to other photographers, notably Baron Raimund von Stillfried. Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Kimbei, or Kinbē, Kusakabe (1841-1932) was a Japanese photographer who first learned the art as an assistant to European photographers Felice Beato and Baron Raimund von Stillfried. Kusakabe soon established his own studio and storefront in Yokohama, becoming a well-respected photographer as well as a souvenir print and photography supplies dealer, and later established a Tokyo branch. Over time he acquired negative stock and perhaps prints from several photographers, including his former mentor, Baron von Stillfried.

A published studio list from about 1893 documents over 2000 images, ranging from portraits of Japanese "types" to landscapes and landmarks in Japan. His photographic work was highly regarded and known for its subtlety and artistic composition.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: All of the components are fragile and delicate, and must be handled with staff supervision.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Collection is in the public domain. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Kimbei Kusakabe photograph album with costumes, portraits, occupations, and views of Japan was received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase in 2015.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Kimbei Kusakabe photograph album with costumes, portraits, occupations, and views of Japan, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: To better preserve the album, whose original enclosures were becoming vulnerable to damage through further use, Conservation staff carefully disassembled it and created three custom boxes for the components. All of the components are fragile and delicate, and must be handled with supervision from staff.

scopecontent.head: Content Description
scopecontent.p: This souvenir folio album from the studio of Japanese photographer Kimbei, or Kinbē, Kusakabe (1841-1932) features 98 hand-colored albumen prints mounted two to a page and originally bound accordion-style, and two additional prints mounted inside the lacquer covers.

The photographic scenes were designed to appeal to tourists, and portray people working at crafts and trades; rice cultivation; tea houses, hotels, gardens, temples, landscapes, and other scenes, mostly in Kyoto, but also including Kobe, Nagasaki, Hone, Yamato, and Arima. Portraits of people include geishas bathing, playing musical instruments, and dressing; samurai warriors and sumo wrestlers; rural people; a physician; a rickshaw and passengers; a funeral; and numerous other subjects typical of these albums. Some of the images have been positively or tentatively attributed to other photographers, notably Baron Raimund von Stillfried.

Most of the photographs bear printed title labels in English. The print mounts measure roughly 10 1/4 x 13 1/4 inches; most of the prints measure roughly 8 3/8 x 10 3/8 inches. Only a handful bear number identifiers but many have been taken from online prints in other collections and from a published studio list, circa 1893.

Included in the collection and housed separately are the original highly decorated black lacquer album covers with ivory and gold relief depicting a man, woman, and small child in a fishing boat; housed in another box is the original embossed silk-lined and padded two-part box, with the photographer's commercial label in English and Japanese. The studio address is given as "Yokohama, 36 and 27 Benten-dori Nichome," dating this album to the period between 1885-1890.
Given its expensive quality, this commercial souvenir album is most likely a unique assemblage of images chosen from the studio list by the intended client, rather than a pre-assembled album.

For preservation purposes, the mounts were separated from the album covers and separately foldered in their original hinged-mount groupings. Color photographic copies of the two prints pasted on the inside covers are available in the last folder of the prints box.
Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

physdesc.physfacet: 98 albumen prints; 2 color copies of original prints

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Titles have been taken from title labels found on almost all the page mounts pasted just below the print; original spellings and punctuation have been retained. Two of the original albumen prints are mounted on the insides of the covers, which are housed separately in another box; color copies for these prints are available in the prints box, in the last folder.
Unlike other souvenir albums, most of the prints in this collection bear no studio identifiers, but there are some with numbers in the negative.

When not present or uncertain, titles and numbers are taken from the Kusakabe Kimbei studio list, circa 1893, in Terry Bennett's Old Japanese photographs: Collectors' data guide, Quaritch, 2006. Variant titles are also noted. Online images from the same negative also have been used to identify prints with no titles or identifiers.

Some prints in the album have been positively or tentatively identified as the work of Kusakabe's former mentor, Baron Raimund von Stillfried. There may be other prints that are the work of other studios, among them perhaps Seibei.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Studio list number (not on print): 1337. Identical online print bears this number.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Studio list number (not on print): 44. There are two images with the same title on the studio list: the identifier 44 appears on an identical online image.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Studio list number (not on print): 38?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Studio list number (not on print): 1346. There are over ten images with similar titles on the studio list: the identifier 1346 appears on an online image identical to this one.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Studio list number (not on print): 1218. An identical online image bears this studio number.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interior scene with physician taking pulse of young person. Studio list number (not on print): 147. Identical online image bears this number.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Number in negative: 891; does not match title on studio list. This title, or any similar one, does not appear on the circa 1893 Kimbei studio list. It may have had this number on an earlier studio list, or have been taken by another photographer, or has a different title altogether on the circa 1893 studio listing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: No number. There are several prints with the same title on the studio list.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Number in negative: 860; does not match title in studio list. Studio list number (not on print): 1308.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: No number. There are several prints with similar titles on the studio list. An online image attributes it to Baron von Stillfried (History Daily on Pinterest).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: No number. Kumamoto Castle in Kumamoto Prefecture. Two prints with this title are on the studio list: 1424 and 1425. This and the next three prints are on hinged, attached mounts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: No number. There are several prints with similar titles on the studio list. This image does not appear to be 172, which is on a similar image at the Getty Museum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: No number. Studio list number (not on print): 164.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Number in negative appears as 691(?) Studio list number (not on print): 1421.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: No number. An identical image in the Getty Museum bears the number 65, which on the Kimbei studio list is titled "Jinrikisha of Maiko-No-Hama." This and the next three prints are on hinged mounts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: No number. There are several studio list numbers for similar titles. Considering the oval frame and style, this may be a Baron von Stillfried negative (compare with P-0017).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: No number. Identical print online is numbered 87. Studio list title for 87: "Coolie, in Snow Costume." This image is also in the Getty collections, but is attributed to Baron von Stillfried.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Studio list number (not on print): 97.

did.unittitle: Daibutsu or Bronze Image at Nara

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Label includes detailed caption about the statue. Number in print: 843. An identical online print carries the number 1243. This and the next three prints are mounted on two hinged boards.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: No number. Portrait of young woman, standing. The Mt. Fuji backdrop can be found in other images of this period and are attributed to Kimbei (see his "Three Girls," number 18, online). An identical online image, however, is attributed to Baron von Stillfried.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: No number. There are several studio list numbers for the same title: 10, 251, and 259. There are Kimbei studio prints online that bear these numbers, but none is the same as this one. Although the tinting is similar to the Kimbei studio's work, the setting and image tonality resemble prints from Kajima Seibei's studio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Studio list number (not on print): 1236.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: No number. Seems to be a photograph of a photo-montage of uncertain authorship. Not the same as the famous "1700 Babies" by Japanese photographer Etaki.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Print is attributed to the photographer Yamamoto (active 1870s) going by the props used in other images known to be by Yamamoto. Yamamoto prints often end up in Kimbei albums in the 1880s. "Basket Seller" (110) by Kimbei is a different image.

did.unittitle: Buddhist Images in Great Gate Chionin, at Kioto

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Probably "Images in Great Gate Chion-In," studio list number 1307, borne by another identical print in another collection. However, number on this print, 859, does not correspond to to the circa 1893 Kimbei studio list.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Studio list number (not on print): 85.

did.unittitle: Chion In, Temple (Great Gate) at Kioto

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Probably "Great Gate in Chion-In Temple," studio list number 1305, borne by another identical online print in another collection. However, number on this print, 857 (in image), does not correspond to the circa 1893 Kimbei studio list.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Studio list number (not on print): 101. An identical online print bears this number.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Studio list number (not on print): 23? An identical print in the Getty Museum bears the negative number 121, titled on the Kimbei studio list as "Playing and Dancing." This and the next five prints are part of a group on three hinged mounts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Image of geishas bathing is attributed by the Getty Museum to Baron von Stillfried. The head of the woman on the right in the Kimbei album print has been replaced by the head of another woman on other prints of the same image, including the one in the Getty Museum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Possible attribution to Baron von Stillfried by the Getty Museum. The same title on the Kimbei studio list carries the number 71, but the image has not been identified with this print.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Number in negative is 856, which does not correspond to titles on circa 1893 studio image list. Identical print online is numbered 1304, which does correspond.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Number in negative is 853, which does not correspond to titles on circa 1893 studio image list. Identical print online is numbered 1301, which does correspond, but is titled "View of Maruyama and Yaami's Hotel."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Number in negative is 878, which does not correspond to titles on circa 1893 studio image list. Identical New York Public Library print is numbered 1326, which does correspond; studio list title is "Gion Street." Gion was a popular geisha district.

did.unittitle: View of Sumiyoshi Bridge at Osaka

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Studio list number (not on print): 1233. Identical print at the Smithsonian numbered in negative 833. Also known as Soribashi Bridge at Sumiyoshi Shrine, as well as Taikobashi (Drum Bridge). This and the next three prints are on hinged mounts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Studio list number (not on print): 109. An identical online print carries this number on a label.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: No number. Title on studio list "Preparing Rice Ground (Ploughing)" is not the same image. There are several prints on the list with the title "Rice planting": number 141 is not this image.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Studio list number (not on print): 1231. Identical print at New York Public Library bears matching studio list number 1231.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This print is mounted to the interior board of the front album cover. A color copy is available in this folder.
Studio list number (not on print): 1208, titled "Metaki or Female Waterfall, Kobe."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This portrait of a young woman is mounted on the interior board of the rear album cover. There is no number. A color viewing copy is available in the collection folder.

An identical print in the Getty Museum is titled "Officer's Daughter," and is attributed to Baron von Stillfried. It was reportedly a popular image and is found in other albums from different studios.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Presentation box and lacquer covers are extremely fragile and must be used under staff supervision.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original black lacquer covers are decorated with ivory and gold inlay. The intricate front cover scene shows a fishing boat on a lake with a man, small child, and a woman catching a lively fish, surveyed by a cormorant on a post high above the water. The back cover features a delicate botanical design inlay. Cover dimensions are 10 3/4 x 13 7/8 inches.

A large-format Kusakabe albumen print is pasted on the inside of each cover. Please do not take covers out of the trays to see these prints: color photocopies are available in the last folder in the prints box.
The original presentation box is made of paper boards with an embossed red and gilt design featuring botanical elements and stylized animals. Dimensions are 11 1/4 x 14 1/2 x 4 1/2 inches.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Presentation box is extremely fragile and must be used with staff supervision.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Lacquer covers are extremely fragile and must be used with staff supervision. Do not take covers out of trays!
Color photocopies of the prints pasted on the inside of each cover are available in the last folder in the prints box.
